jeopardy_round: HOW ABOUT A LITTLE ROMANCE LANGUAGE?

(1, 1).clue: Part of this big state crosses the 180th meridian of longitude

(2, 1).clue: Since 1979 it's been tempting the "tummy with the taste of nuts & honey"

(3, 1).clue: She's the lass in the Stephen Foster ditty heard here

(5, 1).clue: Tobey Maguire said kissing Kirsten Dunst upside-down in the rain was the hardest thing he's done as this superhero

(6, 1).clue: Around the Vatican you might be able to practice this source language of all Romance languages

(1, 2).clue: With a population of about 120,000, Columbia is this state's most populous city

(2, 2).clue: As its name suggests, this General Mills cereal provides 100% daily value of 12 vitamins & minerals

(3, 2).clue: Aye, aye!  It's the title of the military anthem heard here

(5, 2).clue: In "To Have and Have Not", she kisses Bogart & says, "It's even better when you help"

(6, 2).clue: Of Catalan, Bulgarian or Romanian, the one that is not a Romance language

(1, 3).clue: These 2 states have the shortest coasts on the Gulf of Mexico, only about 50 miles apiece

(2, 3).clue: About a third of all Life cereal sold is of this flavor introduced in 1978

(3, 3).clue: You might need to join A.A. if you take this song literally

(5, 3).clue: A mutt & a cocker spaniel slurp spaghetti & smooch in this 1955 classic

(6, 3).clue: It's the most widely spoken Romance language in the world

(1, 4).clue: This state has the highest average altitude of any state east of the Mississippi; must be pretty "mountainous"

(2, 4).clue: Introduced in the 1980s, it's the trademark name for a cereal of "seven whole grains & sesame" & little puffs

(3, 4).clue: Some big gloves might be a nice present for the guy in this song heard here
(3, 4).correct response: "He\'s Got The Whole World In His Hands"

(4, 4).clue: Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management

(5, 4).clue: 1940s classic film in which the heroine says, "Kiss me.  Kiss me as if it were the last time"

(6, 4).clue: Ligurian, Lombard & Piedmontese are all dialects of this Romance language

(1, 5).clue: Tears were shed when the Teddy Bear Museum in Naples in this state closed its doors forever in 2005

(2, 5).clue: This cereal from Kellogg's is "crispy rice on one side, crunchy corn on the other"

(3, 5).clue: They're the dancing title females in the song heard here

(4, 5).correct response: the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD)

(5, 5).clue: 1981 drama in which Norman Thayer asks wife Ethel, "Wanna dance or would you rather just suck face?"

(6, 5).clue: Linguists trace Romance languages back to this hyphenated family of languages

(1, 1).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew delivers the clue from Kyoto, Japan.)  Among the many utensils used in the ceremony are the chashaku, or scoop, & a chasen, or wisk, made from a single piece of this

(2, 1).clue: Nessus, one of these half-horse creatures, tried to abduct Hercules' wife; big mistake

(3, 1).clue: It created an all-water link from NYC to the Great Lakes & opened up the settlement of the Great Lakes area

(4, 1).clue: Of U.S. News & Word Report's 5 top U.S. hospitals in pediatrics, 4 include these 2 words in their names

(6, 1).clue: Battles between these fighters in the Roman Colosseum were stopped in 404 A.D.

(1, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew delivers the clue from Kyoto, Japan.) Crawling or crouching through the door to enter the room signifies kenson, Japanese for this 8-letter opposite of pride

(2, 2).clue: Every 500 years or so, this bird was reborn from its own ashes

(3, 2).clue: On May 10, 1869 telegraph operators in Utah signaled the nation that this had been completed

(4, 2).clue: There's a stroke center at Boswell Hospital in this Arizona retirement city

(6, 2).clue: Bartenders use it to make an orange blossom

(1, 3).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew delivers the clue from Kyoto, Japan.) Like the altar of a Zen chapel which inspired it, the tokonoma, a decorated alcove, faces this direction, thought lucky due to its exposure to sunlight

(2, 3).clue: The Nemean Lion was the sibling of this monster who liked to riddle people with her own riddle before eating them

(3, 3).clue: This 1862 act gave 160 acres of free land to anyone who had lived on it & improved it for 5 years

(4, 3).clue: An L.A. "home for the incurables" named for this holy mountain later merged with Cedars of Lebanon

(5, 3).clue: "The Agony and the Ecstasy" &"You Only Live Twice"

(6, 3).clue: These large masses of slow-moving ice occur where winter snowfall exceeds summer melt

(1, 4).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew delivers the clue from Kyoto, Japan.) Many elements of the ceremony like the fire & water, the open tea bowl & the closed tea caddy, represent these two complementary forces of nature borrowed from the Chinese

(2, 4).clue: It wasn't hard for this Lernaean serpent to get ahead; every time one of its heads was cut off, 2 grew in its place

(3, 4).clue: In the 1846 Oregon Treaty, the British gave up claims to all territory below the 49th parallel except this large island

(4, 4).clue: London's HTD, Hospital for these Diseases, has a consultant parasitologist & leprologist

(6, 4).clue: Rich in phosphates, this waste matter left by bats & seabirds can be a valuable commodity

(1, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew delivers the clue from Kyoto, Japan.) Once, sitting on these mats could signify one's noble stature; today, everyone sits on them for the tea ceremony

(2, 5).clue: She was a beautiful nymph before she was turned into a sea monster, doomed to live in a cave opposite Charybdis

(3, 5).clue: This 1853 deal that brought the U.S. chunks of New Mexico & Arizona is known in Mexico as the sale of La Mesilla

(4, 5).clue: Seen here is this fittingly named Paris complex founded as a veterans' hospital by Louis XIV

(6, 5).clue: In construction, it's a horizontal load-bearing structural member

(0, 0).clue: This term for a deadly substance may derive from the name of a love goddess
